metadata.titleEn: Chemical composition of micas in Gyirong leucogranite and pegmatite in Himalayan orogen
metadata.description: The Gyirong pluton is located in the middle of the Himalayan orogenic belt with the outcrops of distinct granitic phases, including two-mica granite and beryl-bearing granitic pegmatite (aplite included). The pluton is located in an area with an anomalous lithium enrichment on the geochemical mapping of lithium distribution in China. In this study, Li-rich micas are found in the Gyirong granitic phases. The texture characteristics are observed and in situ major and trace element compositions of micas are analyzed by using scanning electron microscope (SEM), electron microprobe analyzer (EMPA) and laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometer (LA-ICP-MS). The micas are indicative for the degree and process of the lithium enrichment during the magmatic and hydrothermal stage.
metadata.instructions: Data stored in Excel format. File name  "WRMajTr" listed major and trace compositions of the whole rock, the filename ”MicaMajTra” listed major and trace element composition of the micas, the file  ”BrlMajTra ” listed the composition of beryl.

literatureList.titleEn: Mineralogical study of mica in Himalayan Jilong light-colored granite - pegmatite: Indications of lithium enrichment processes.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key features and techniques used in collecting and analyzing geochemical data of muscovite and beryl minerals in the context of the Gyirong pluton in Tibet?
Feature Specification.Answer: whole-rock geochemical major element data, trace element data, electron probe analysis, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS)

Quantification.Question: How many types of geochemical data are obtained from the samples in a dataset related to the Himalayan Gyirong leucogranite-pegmatite?

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the geochemical processes and mineral composition trends from the analysis of major and trace elements in micas and beryl collected from the Tibetan Gyirong body?
Interpretation.Answer: The geochemical processes and mineral composition trends can be inferred by analyzing the major and trace elements in micas and beryl. Micas, being effective indicators, can reveal the degree and processes of lithium enrichment in the rock body. The use of wet chemical analysis for major elements and ICP-MS for trace elements, along with electron probe analysis and ICP-MS for minerals, helps elucidate the formation and alteration mechanisms within the Gyirong rock body.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of collecting and analyzing major and trace elements data from minerals like micas and beryl in granitic-pegmatitic systems within the Tibetan region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to understand the composition of micas and their role as indicators of lithium enrichment processes in granitic-pegmatitic systems. By analyzing major and trace elements in these minerals, researchers aim to determine the extent and mechanisms of lithium enrichment within the rock body, which is significant for geological and mineral exploration purposes.
